Title:
Diversity of Claviceps paspali based on RAPD and ergot
alkaloids and indole diterpenes genes reveals unknown lineages and
unique alkaloid profiles
Abstract:
Claviceps species affecting Paspalum spp. have become a
serious problem for agriculture as they infect forage grasses like
Paspalum dilatatum Poir and P. plicatulum Michx producing the ergot
disease. The ascomycete C. paspali is known as the main responsible for
this disease in both grasses. This fungus produces alkaloids including
ergot alkaloids (EAs) and indole diterpenes (IDT) which have potent
neurotropic activities in mammals. A total of 32 isolates from Uruguay
were obtained from infected P. dilatatum and P. plicatulum. Isolates
were phylogenetically identified using sequences of the translation
elongation factor 1-alfa and the beta tubulin genes, genotyped with RAPD
and markers representing peripheral genes within the EA and IDT alkaloid
biosynthetic clusters, and their alkaloid potential was predicted. The
results from this study provide insight into the genotypic and
chemotypic diversity of Claviceps paspali present in P. dilatatum and
suggest that isolates from P. plicatulum could be considered an
ecological subspecies or specialized variant of C. paspali. Some of
these isolates show hypothetical alkaloid profiles never reported
before.
